title: work-taking-place-upgrade-drift-path-musselburgh-wallyford
story: Wimpey East Scotland said the improvements to the walkway, next to its Almond Park development at Pinkie, got under way last Wednesday and would take about four to five weeks to complete.A new surfaced path will be laid three metres in width to ensure it is fully accessible for a range of users.The section of pathway, which extends from the car park at Pinkie Terrace in Musselburgh to the underpass at the railway line, will also benefit from new street lighting which will be installed.There is no access to The Drt during the work in the interests of health and safety, the company stressed.Pauline Mills, land  planning director for Taylor Wimpey East Scotland, said: ldquoWe do hope these path improvement works will be welcomed locally and we apologise in advance for any inconvenience they may experience while the current path is closed to all users.ldquoAn information postcard will be distributed to all properties within the Almond Park development this week to let them know about the work that will be taking place.ldquoShould anyone have any concerns, please email sarah.patonbutler@taylorwimpey

title: msp-praises-volunteer-centre-critical-lifeline-visit
story: The comments follow South Scotland MSP Craig Hoyrsquos visit to the Tranent-based facility.The centre is a third-sector interface which provides support to voluntary organisations across East Lothian through partnership projects.This has included working in partnership with Musselburgh-based Paragon Products to deliver cleaning supplies to support the opening of community and third-sector organisations.During his visit, Mr Hoy met with the centrersquos chief officer Maureen Allan, discussing some of the challenges and opportunities the easing of lockdown restrictions had presented for the voluntary sector.The High Street facility also operates a childrenrsquos befriending service, supported hospital discharge programme, community taskforce service for those isolated during lockdown, a free community pantry and provides access to computers for those who struggle with technology.Working with East Lothian Councilrsquos connected communities team, the countyrsquos health and social care partnership and other third-sector organisations in the county, the volunteer centre provides free, confidential advice and support for residents and support for small local third-sector groups.Mr Hoy said: ldquoVolunteer Centre East Lothian has become an essential service for many residents and organisations during this dficult period. The staff and volunteers are a critical leline for local residents.ldquoI would like to extend my thanks to Maureen for welcoming me to the centre and for her wider work fundraising.Maureen said: ldquoOur communities, the third sector and statutory partners have shown how much can be achieved by working together. The pandemic made a lot of people re-evaluate their lives. Many residents volunteered their time and it was great to see the real community spirit that has been lost over the years resurface.To contact the centre, call  , email info@volunteereastlothian.org.uk or visit volunteereastlothian.org.uk

title: looking-back-turnpike-tolls-east-lothian
story: The first turnpike road was set up in  for sections of the Great North Road in Hertfordshire, Bedfordshire and Huntingdonshire.In spite of some early problems, with angry yokels kicking open the turnpikes or beating up the tollkeepers, these turnpikes soon became a profitable venture they spread, like a contagion, all over England and Wales.The Act of Union in  opened the Scottish Border to the turnpike road system, the first one being constructed on a road in Midlothian in .East Lothian also developed a healthy population of turnpikes and tollhouses, supported by the local authorities but far from popular among the locals.There was a turnpike on the main road through Aberlady, with the tollhouse still standing to this day.There was at least one turnpike road through Haddington one near the Town Hall at Dunbarrsquos High Street one on the main road between Dunbar and North Berwick, and two more at Belhaven and Kirk Hill near Dunbar.Usually, a turnpike and tollhouse was put up by the authorities, with the top bid being pocketed for use in road maintenance, and the poor tollkeeper left to a boring and onerous task collecting the tolls to recompensate himself.When I was researching my book Phillimorersquos East Lothian, I noted a quaint card of lsquoCleikum Toll, Dunbarrsquo: a bucolic scene of a small cottage, with a woman standing in the doorway and a shepherd, eight sheep and a sheepdog passing it by. The card had superior artistic merit and I wanted to make use of it in the book, which was to include a number of old cards by the celebrated North Berwick postcard artist Reginald Phillimore.The problem, however, was that no information was forthcoming where this obscure cottage had been or how it had earnt sufficient fame to be depicted by Phillimore.The book was published in  without lsquoCleikum Tollrsquo being featured.The purchase of another Edwardian postcard belatedly solved the mystery in August : it turned out that the careless Phillimore had got the name wrong, since it was not lsquoCleikum Tollrsquo but lsquoCleikimin Tollrsquo!And indeed, inquiries demonstrated that this turnpike and tollhouse had been standing at the cross between the road from Dunbar to Spott and the road from Broxburn to Belton. It is likely there were two turnpikes, one on each road. The tollhouse was said to be very old, quite possibly constructed in the first half of the th century.In early Victorian times, the tollgate system kept flourishing all over Britain. In rural west Wales, there were full-scale riots in  after a number of novel turnpikes had been erected, something the locals disapproved of. Men dressed as women attacked the turnpikes and beat up the tollkeepers, and it was only with dficulty they could be pacied.Cleikimin Toll was spared such indignities, however: it was still operational at the time of the Ordnance Survey of -. The name-book of this survey [OS    ] refers to it as a ldquoA Toll Bar at a junction of roads situated about half a mile south of the town of Dunbar.A note explains Cleikimin as a name usually applied to a cheap public house, where a Cleik [Scottish for fish-hook] was supposed to have been made use of to pull the customers inside.The arrival of the railways did much damage to the old tollgate system all over Britain: as a result, the road toll revenue plummeted and the tollkeepers grumbled incessantly.The Scottish municipal authorities realised the old-fashioned turnpikes were on the way out, and by  they were all gone.The tollhouse at Cleikimin Toll stood well into Edwardian times, being admired as a quaint relic of olden days. It survived the Great War but was destroyed not long after in a scheme for widening the A. Thistly Cross Roundabout today stands on the spot.

title: north-berwick-home-branded-grand-designs-experiment-approved
story: Architect Robin Sutherland saw his vision of a family home on North Berwickrsquos High Street turned down by East Lothian Councilrsquos planning committee.The proposals, recommended for approval by planning officers, were rejected by a single vote.Mr Sutherland, who works in the town, appealed to Scottish Ministers to see the plans given the green light.Rosie Leven, the reporter appointed by the Scottish Ministers, gave the planned three-storey building at  High Street and land to the north the go ahead.Neighbours overlooking the proposed three-bedroom house had objected to the planned property, which measures just over four metres wide and  metres long, on the grounds of privacy.Mrs Leven attached a condition to the approval that a balustrade should be included on the roof terrace.She said: ldquoI consider that the proposed first floor kitchen doors and roof terrace are part of the main living space of the proposed house and are likely to be more regularly used, during a larger proportion of the day, than the bedroom windows.ldquoI consider that it is from those first floor windows spaces that there is the greatest potential for an adverse effect on neighbouring residential amenity.ldquoIn this respect, the appellant has suggested that a condition could be placed on the consent to require a . metre balustrade around the three open sides of the roof terrace.ldquoIn the circumstances, I find that such a balustrade would help to reduce the ability for overlooking, both from the roof terrace itself and from the double doors to the kitchen.ldquoTaking this into account, I accept that there may be some overlooking from and to the proposed bedroom window, but with the addition of a balustrade, I consider that the overall impact on the amenity of the neighbouring properties would not be signicantly adverse.Concerns had also been raised about whether the proposed building was in keeping with the character of the town centre.The Reporter noted that traditional buildings ldquodominate the area but added ldquothere are dferent heights and styles of building.She said there was ldquono consistent building line on Forth Street and the character is one of buildings offset from each other, providing interesting views and angles.The proposals originally went before the local authorityrsquos planning committee in January, with six of the  councillors voting to reject the plans.Councillor Jane Henderson was joined by fellow North Berwick Coastal ward members Jim Goodfellow and Jeremy Findlay in speaking out against the plans.She told the committee that the width of the home would be ldquonot much wider than a shipping container, my goodness gracious.She said: ldquoI am not convinced this is the best place for a Grand Designs experiment, adding: ldquoJust because theoretically it can be done does not make it right.Grand Designs is a popular and long-running home improvements television show presented by Kevin McCloud where unique and daringly designed homes are built.

title: maths-teacher-stars-popular-tv-show-countdown
story: Steven Grady appeared on two episodes of the Channel  show, which sees two contestants compete through three types of rounds ndash a letters round, numbers round and conundrum round.Mr Grady won the numbers round on his first episode and tied with his opposition during the numbers round on his second episode.Countdown is hosted by Anne Robinson ndash the first female host of Channel s longest running series.Contestants stay on the show until they either lose a game or retire undefeated as an lsquoOctochamprsquo after eight wins.Mr Grady won his first episode - against a contestant who had previously won four games. In his second episode, he lost - on a crucial conundrum.Mr Grady, who lives in Edinburgh, joined the PL staff team in August .He said: ldquoI applied for Countdown in June  but, due to Covid restrictions, I couldnrsquot get down to the studio.ldquoI applied after watching a few shows through lockdown and thinking I would like having a go at it. title: calls-made-post-covid-review-gp-needs-wallyford-houses-approved
story: East Lothian Councils planning committee granted detailed planning permission for the new Taylor Wimpey homes as part of development of the site south of Wallyford.However, concerns were raised that no new discussions had been held with health chiefs over the need for additional GP services to serve the new housing.Musselburgh GP practices have comeunder pressure in recent years, as newbuilds bring more families into the area, leading to a number of calls for action from the community and politicians.Councillor Norman Hampshire, planning convenor, told the virtual planning committee meeting that he was surprised no talks with health bosses had been held since the early days of the masterplan for the -hectare site, which was first lodged in .He said: ldquoObviously from the timesince the masterplan was approved and these applications, a lot has happened: the growth in population,plus the cases of Covid and pressures on GP practices in the Musselburgh area.ldquoYou would think there would have been at least further discussion with the NHS regarding the current situation.David Taylor, from the councilrsquos planning department, said that the number of houses planned for the land was still well below those approved in the masterplan when NHS bosses were consulted.He said that the original masterplanapproved had included the formation of , houses, adding that to date only  had come forward.ldquoThis application will take it over , but it is still short of the , which discussions took place on during the planning application in principle on medical provision, he said.Councillors approved the new houses on land in the south east of the site.However, ward councillor Colin McGinn called on NHS Lothian and the Scottish Government to urgently assess the situation at the Wallyford development.He said: ldquoMy overarching point is the provision of medical facilities for this area and the concerns we have had particularly over the last  months and what wersquove got is running out of space and itrsquos not going to meet the need of a developing community."This problem is not going to go away.The committee also unanimously approveddetails for title: haddington-pipe-band-launches-calendar-help-celebrate-40th-birthday
story: Haddington Pipe Band is toasting its th year and released its annual calendar in the town last Saturday.Alastair Bruce, a board member of the band, was pleased to say the calendar, which has a theme of lsquoAnd the Band Playedrsquo, had proven popular.He said: ldquoThe response has been great. We have had really good support from sponsors again and we just launched it last Saturday.ldquoWe got a good number of folk turning up at that and now I am just about to take it out to the shops and other outlets who are selling it for us.ldquoThe Loft has got the exhibition of the calendarrsquos photographs and that is there until January.ldquoObviously, wersquove not been able to play this last couple of years until the last month or so.ldquoWe were not able to take new shots so we have looked back over the last few years and sourced photographs of the band in action.ldquoThe theme is lsquoAnd the Band Playedrsquo and each month is us playing at galas, at a wedding, a festival, on stage in France and just dferent types of events that we have covered here and further afield over the years.Mr Bruce was expecting some of the calendars to make their way over the English Channel but that is not the only far-flung destination.He said: ldquoOne of the first calendars is going to Australia. That is fairly typical and they have gone to India, Spain, the USA, Canada, Africa ndash itrsquos really good.Photographs have been provided by regular supporters of the band, including Nick Callaghan and Garry Menzies.The pipe band attracts members aged from eight to , with more than a dozen pipers and a number of drummers.However, the past  months have seen the band sidelined when it comes to getting out in the community.Mr Bruce told the Courier that plans to mark the th year were being drawn up, although it depended upon coronavirus restrictions remaining eased.He added: ldquoWe would probably have made a bit more of a song and dance about itthings had been dferent.ldquoWe are back out playing now and were at the farmersrsquo market last Saturday, as well as doing the launch.ldquoWe have been to a wedding and doing other things as well.ldquoWe have not been able to practise together but have been doing Zoom calls every week, which sounds ridiculous but we have been doing that and playing on the chanter rather than the full pipes.The calendar, which costs pound, is a key part of the bandrsquos fundraising, with the money going to unorms, instruments, tuition and other initiatives.Mr Bruce added: ldquoPeople in the band donrsquot pay for their unorms, there is no subscription to be a band member and we try to keep it so anybody can join and play.ldquoWe provide instruments and all that costs quite a lot of money.ldquoThe secret of the calendar is that we try to get something that people are happy to have on their walls.ldquoPeople buy it to support us but we want to have good photographs so people enjoy having it on their walls.

title: big-hare-trail-auction-see-hare-sold-ones-staying-east-lothian
story: The total, which included pound, paid for the golfing-themed Hare Tae Golf sculpture, is enough for Leuchie to fund the equivalent of four specialist nurses for a year.It also helps plug a gap in funding needed to run the national respite centre, near North Berwick, as it continues to recover from the pandemic, providing holiday breaks to people affected by neurological conditions such as MS, MND and stroke.The six-foot statues, which delighted people this summer as part of The Big Hare Trail celebrating Leuchies th anniversary as an independent charity, went under the hammer at a grand auction at the Marine Hotel in North Berwick last Friday evening.The  hares sold on the night were: Hare Brained pound, Wild Thing pound, Race The Wind pound, Ocean View pound, Hare Tae Golf pound, Molly Hare  Friends pound, Sky  Sea pound, Over The Rainbow pound, Woodland Creature pound, Unlocking East Lothian pound, Mystery Harepound,.Further good news saw most of the hares staying in East Lothian for the public to enjoy, after several local campaigns resulted in winning bids on the night.The golfing hare proved the hottest property at Fridays auction ndash compered by BBC broadcaster Glenn Campbell and overseen by May Matthews of auctioneers Bonhams.After a flurry of bids from the floor, The Renaissance Club won with a bid of pound,, bringing the hare back to the course it graced during the Scottish Open.Thanks to a collective of donors who pooled resources in support of Leuchie, two hares ndash Sky  Sea and Molly Hare  Friends ndash were secured for the charity itself.One of them will take pride at place at Leuchie, while the other will be located at Denis Duncan House, the accessible holiday cottage near Dirleton that the charity will manage from next year.Another successful community bid sparked an emotional round of applause, as Kirsty Herriots fundraising campaign to keep her daughter Abbies creation Ocean View local paid off when it was sold for pound,.Kirsty, who now hopes to put the hare in the country park being created by North Berwick Trust to the south of the town, said: "What a nerve-wracking evening!"Winning Abbies Hare was beyond my wildest dreams, but we did it. The big cheer at the end just resulted in me bursting into tears! Thank you to every single one of you who helped make this happen, you have no idea how happy you have made me."The bidder who won Wild Thing confirmed that the hare would be staying in North Berwick and "will be able to see the sea", while Over The Rainbow will also be staying in East Lothian at Papple Steading, between Stenton and Gford.George Mackintosh, owner of Papple Steading, said: "The hares location will be surrounded by bird boxes, rustic shelters and tables, boardwalks and pathways."Its wonderful at the same time to support a local charity with such a nationally important purpose."Lana Banbridge, head of fundraising and communications at Leuchie, said: "This funding is critical, as our efforts to fundraise continue to be limited by the pandemic."This funding will pay for half of our specialist nursing team, who enable our guests to live le to their fullest during their stay with us, safe in the knowledge that they are receiving the highest quality of care."Those who were able to be with us on Friday heard from a regular guest to Leuchie, Graeme. His ethos and advice mirrors that which sits at the core of all that we do here: Dont think about what you cant do, focus on what you can."Stephen Pearson, chair of Leuchie House, said: "Were immensely proud of what the Big Hare Trail has achieved ndash for the artists who did such amazing designs, the businesses who sponsored them and the people of all ages from all over the world who enjoyed all of these beautul works of art."It brought true joy at a very dficult time."To have raised signicantly more than we expected from the auction is a huge boost for our charity, enabling the team at Leuchie to continue to provide respite breaks for people from across Scotland who desperately need them."

story: Covid- and Brexit are among contributing factors, while an escalating dispute over fishing rights has led French fishing representatives to threaten a blockade at Calais to stop exports to the UK.Current issues have been put down to a "transition period" by Boris Johnsons administration, which they say will not cause "much risk" at Christmas.However, asindustry experts deemChristmas shortages "a certainty", making your own presents could help you to avoid potential delays or disappointment.Not only that, but family and friends are sure to appreciate the time andeffort that goes into creating ahand crafted gt.Here are some ideas for homemade presents this Christmas...The festive period is a time for eating, so what better than cooking up a big batch of homemade jam or chutney for your loved ones.Start saving your jars now and by Christmas you will have plenty to fill.Hundreds of recipes can be found online andyou are cooking in large quantities, it wont necessarily be that expensive!Another positive is the long shelf le of such products, meaning people can enjoy them well into .Christmas tree decorationsare an underrated gt - title: letters-early-compare-results-home-nations-handled-covid
story: Apart from still being too soon to compare results across the UK , one might expect England to fare worse than Scotland. Englandrsquos population density is much greaterwe have no equivalent to Londonrsquos population or its densitynor to Englandrsquos other congested areasand we have far fewer ethnic minorities who may possibly be more susceptible to Covid and who do seem more averse to vaccination.It is easy for Ms Thomas to condemn the PM for not closing down the UK sooner. But in early March and in some cases for weeks thereafter, SAGE advisers were dismissive or ided about closing airports and schools, preventing large gatherings outside, wearing face masks and even about testingrsquos efficacy.Transfers from hospitals to care homes, without testing, were made in all parts of the UK. The often-criticised ldquoherd immunity was advocated by Professor Chris Whitty and Sir Patrick Vallance until mid-March and they both warned that a lockdown too soon would not be sustained long enough by the public. The PM implemented lockdown on March , within days of their changed advice based on the Imperial College projections on March .All UK governments have tried to manage near-impossible balancing acts between lives and livelihoods, physical and mental health, short-term and long-term effects, the old and young, and the huge financial and other costs inherent in all such decisions ndash all while hearing dfering opinions from dferent experts. The right time for comparing results will probably not be until March , when with luck we can say the pandemic is overand two full years of data are available for comprehensive and credible comparisons.John Birkett, St Andrews.MY FEAR OVER COP PROTESTSAROUND , delegates from all over the world will arrive in Glasgow next month to hold wide-ranging discussions that are focused on climate change. The people who are most vocerous and physically active in the demand for change will be turning up in their thousands to protest .Has no one noticed the irony of protesting about a summit that is trying to address the very issues the protestors demand that we address  The right to peaceful protest is essential in a democracy. However, respect for fellow citizens must be considered. The recent blockages at the M were, in my view, ill-conceived and caused serious hardship for many citizens who also support the need to address climate change.My fear is that peaceful protesters in Glasgow will be infiltrated by people seeking to raise the temperature by engaging in seriously disruptive actions and possibly violence.I hope Irsquom proved wrong but I fear the worst.John Gilligan, Ayr.THE STATE OF MODERN GLASGOWGLASGOW City Council leader Susan Aitken talks of "modern Glasgow" and "a chance to put the city in worlds shop window" .Is the modern Glasgow the one with the litter-strewn streets, the one with graffiti everywhere you look, the one with the potholed streets and broken pavements, the one with the vacant shops and business premises in its city centre, the one where the buses stop running at pm, the one where the subway shuts at six on a Sunday or is it the one that only exists in the imagination of a leader who surely cannot have recently ventured forth onto the streets of our once-proud city William Gold, Glasgow.HAVE WE TOO MANY THINKERS Are we producing far too many "thinkers", and far too few doers Would we not be better to give far more young people opportunities to learn skills which are in demand and which lead to a good income and a future Penny Ponders, Edinburgh.THE MINERS GENTLEMANS CLUBSTUART Waitons column about the attitudes of the criminal justice system towards malesreminds me of story from a previous age, in which two hooligans were charged with attacking and robbing an old guy ing after an evening at his Miners Welfare."Excuse me," asked the judge of the prosecutor, "whats this "miners welfare that you are talking about " "Well, mlud", replied the prosecutor, "its a sort of mens club." "My goodness", exclaimed the judge, "it has come to a pretty pass when a gentleman cannot walk home from his club of an evening without being accosted by footpads."Needless to say, the "footpads" felt the full weight of the law as a result.Professor KB Scott, Stirling.

title: green-scots-public-sector-pension-fund-rejects-virtue-signalling-fossil-fuel-divestment
story: The Lothian Pension Fund has hit back at calls to move its investments to help curb the climate crisis ahead of the  United Nations Climate Change Conferencein Glasgow saying it did not want to indulge in "virtue signalling".It came after it emerged its investment in fossil fuels rose by % in a year.New data showed that the fund which supports over , employees is investing in BP, Chevron, Exxon and Shell, as well as in mining giant BHP.Green campaigners have raised concern that there is "inaction inertia" with no move to est from fossil fuels.Climate activists from campaign group Divest Lothian staged a protest outside Edinburgh City Chambers on Monday to demand the pension fund, removes this money from investments which they say is fuelling the climate crisis.They have raised concern that as The City of Edinburgh Council pledged to become a net-zero carbon city by  and Midlothian, West Lothian and East Lothian Councils declared a climate emergency in , the Lothian Pension Fund has "continued to profit" from some of the coal, oil and gas companies which they say are most responsible for the climate crisis.Shell is one of the owners of the controversial Cambo oil field, situated off the coast of Shetland, which campaigners are currently fighting to stop going ahead.The Lothian Pension Fund, overseen by the City of Edinburgh Council, is among a record number of signatories to a joint global investor statement calling on governments to urgently ramp up their efforts to address the climate crisis.The Investor Agendarsquos  Global Investor Statement to Governments on the Climate Crisis contains the collective views of  major investors from around the world, representing around  per cent of global assets under management.And in June a new ldquostatement of responsible investment principles from the pension fund says that ldquoclimate change is undoubtedly one of the defining issues of our time and that its commitments going forward include ceasing ldquoprimary investment in companies that arenrsquot aligned with the goals of the Paris agreement.Almost  countries ratied the Paris climate accord at COP six years ago agreeing to pursue efforts to limit the planetrsquos temperature increase to .C above pre-industrial levels.But research has found the pension fundrsquos fossil fuel investments have risen by pound million since  and now stands at poundm.The value of its energy holdings is higher than in  asstock prices have risen by more than % over the last  months.In June, the International Energy Agencysaid that the worldrsquos demand for oil will rebound to pre-pandemic levels by the end of , as recovering economies require oil-producing countries to pump more fossil fuels.But the Lothian Pension Fund is resisting calls for estment from fossil fuel companies - saying it prefers to enact change from the inside.A spokesman said: "The Fundrsquos position is... itfavours a policy of engagement with companies as opposed to estment of shares."Divestment campaigners think that selling shares changes carbon emissions and that companies disappear. That is simply not the case. Reduced emissions are achieved by changing company strategy, government policy and inidual choices. The fund is concentrating on real world decarbonisation outcomes, not virtue signalling."The spokesman also pointed out that the fund owns a higher percentage of assets in renewables than it does in traditional fossil fuel energy companies.ldquoWhat we know about the transition is that it will be long and complex. Fossil fuels will, in fact, be required in signicant quantity to effect the transition that we all want," the fund said.Fund chief exectuiveDavid Vallery said:ldquoWe support the transition to a carbon free economy and at LPF we are confident we are doing our part. We use ourinvestments and engage with companies seeking positivechange and invest in wind, solar and hydro to provide renewable alternatives.The Lothian Pension Fund is the second largest local government pension scheme in Scotland and administers the pension funds of over , members from The City of Edinburgh Council and three other local authorities in the Lothians. It also manages the pensions of  employers, including Scottish Water, Edinburgh Napier University, Lothian Buses and Heriot Watt University.The study carried out by Friends of the Earth Scotland checked the fund for investments against the Carbon Underground  - a list of the largest owners of carbon reserves.Iain Struthers from Divest Lothian said: "It is deeply inconsistent and morally unjustiable that Edinburgh City Council is positioning itself to be a zero-carbon city by , but with no mention of esting its interests in fossil fuels."Stakeholder engagement will never change the core business model of polluting companies. Divestment is an essential step to accelerate the just transition to a sustainable future for all."It comes as activists Extinction Rebellion plan to hold a protest on the streets of Edinburgh this month against a backdrop of the COP  climate conference in Glasgow.The th UN climate conference will see world leaders descend on Scotland to discuss the way forward in tackling environmental issues.But, Extinction Rebellion describe the conference as ldquosystematically corrupted by vested interests and have vowed to do their level best to disrupt proceedings.The activist group have sent the City of Edinburgh Council notication of their plans to hold a protest parade through the streets of the capital on October .The City of Edinburgh Council was approached for comment.

title: scottish-job-vacancies-near-record-levels-candidate-numbers-plummet---report
story: The Royal Bank of Scotlandrsquos report on jobs recorded the third sharpest growth of new appointments on record, with similarly high demand for workers.But the survey of businesses in September found the second fastestdecline of applicants for permanent jobs since records began in , with firms citing Brexit and pandemic uncertainty as the key factors.:Concern for , Scots jobs in jeopardy as furlough ends next weekThe industries with the highest rate of vacancies were the IT and computing sectors, followed by engineering and construction, and then the accountancy and financial sectors.Hospitality has been hit hardSebastian Burnside, chief economist at the Royal Bank of Scotland, said: ldquoScotland saw a further rapid uplt in hiring activity during September, with the rates of increase in both permanent placements and temp billings easing only slightly from the all-time records seen in August.:Too much intensity as job satisfaction lsquolevels downrsquoldquoThis rounded off a third quarter of unprecedented hiring activity as the Scottish labour market continues to rebound.ldquoMeanwhile, vacancies for both short-term and permanent staff rose at near-record rates during September, but recruiters widely reported skills shortages as the supply of candidates continued to plummet.ldquoThese shortages are likely to become more pronounced over the coming months and may pose some signicant challenges for companies seeking to fill roles and expand their operations.

story: A new charity is on the hunt for budding artists to use their creative flair to design a new logo.Inclusive Orkney is launching a competition — open to all primary and secondary-aged children — to make a new logo, and play an important role in bringing a fresh new charity to the minds of the Orkney public.As an added incentive, the lucky winner will also receive a prize from Grooves.Inclusive Orkney has the overarching aim to support children with additional needs and their families.Chairwoman Karin Spence — an additional support teacher at Glaitness School — says the group started when she, and a parent of a child with additional support needs, and fellow primary teacher Caroline Heddle, started talking about the need for outside school activities for children with additional support needs.Mrs Spence said: “As we are a new charity we do not as of yet have a logo, and we were hoping that we could call upon the talents of local folk to help us with this.“The competition is open to all primary and secondary-aged children.“The winner of the chosen design, which will be picked by members of the Inclusive Orkney charity, will be invited along to our official launch night to see their logo design on a banner and receive a fabulous prize from Grooves.“We would really like our logo to fully encapsulate what Inclusive Orkney is all about.”Logo entries should be created on one sheet of A paper, with your name and phone number clearly written on the back, then submitted to Glaitness Primary School in Kirkwall, FAO Karin Spence no later than Friday, October .copy The Orcadian - A ision of Orkney Media Group Ltd Co. title: folk invited to walk through islands deal proposals for world heritage site
story: Community views are being sought on options for the future management of the Heart of Neolithic Orkney World Heritage Site , which includes Skara Brae, Ring of Brodgar, Stones of Stenness and Maeshowe chambered tomb.Next week, there will be an opportunity for folk to get an inside view of proposals, during in-person consultation sessions in Kirkwall and Stenness.Known as the Orkney Gateway Programme, the proposals aim to provide a more in-depth experience for visitors from home and away across the WHS and generate opportunities for Orkney folk through a more responsible and sustainable approach to tourism.The programme proposes improved signage, technology to monitor visitor numbers in real time and apps to suggest alternative attractions. Proposals also include “active travel” routes, e-bike chargers and welcome facilities, alongside coach permits and charging at some car parks.The programme is being funded with joint investment of up to £. million from the Scottish Government and UK Government, as part of the Islands Growth Deal — a ten-year investment programme jointly funded by the UK and Scottish governments, the three island councils and their partners from the public, academic and business sectors.During the in-person sessions, due to take place next Tuesday and Wednesday, attendees will be guided through proposals with representatives from project partners.OIC leader, Councillor James Stockan, said: “The Islands Deal commitment we have from the Scottish and UK Governments to support the Orkney Gateway is hugely gratying and reflects the position our World Heritage Site holds as one of the jewels in Scotland’s and indeed the UK’s tourism crown — not to mention the global archaeological signicance of the site.“But we must remember that at the core of this is a landscape and series of monuments which for many Orcadians is a direct, mysterious and powerful link to their past. And we know equally they are held very dear by people who’ve moved into these islands over the years.“So, as partners, we are all very clear that we want to gather local people’s views on the range of options that we could bid for through our final Islands Deal business case.”The consultation events are scheduled for Tuesday, October , at Maeshowe Visitor Centre, Stenness, from pm to pm, and Wednesday, October , at St Magnus Centre, Kirkwall, from pm until pm.If you’re unable to attend these events, further information is available at www.orkney.gov.uk orkneygateway. title: information session to showcase self driving vehicles
story: Folk are to be able to find out more about a pilot project exploring the use of autonomous — or self-driving — vehicles .An information session is due to take place at the Orkney Research and Innovation Campus in Stromness next week, Thursday, October .The trial is one of four pilot projects running in the North Sea region as part of the Planning for Autonomous Vehiclesproject, which will explore how autonomous vehicles could interact with existing modes of transport.Folk will have the opportunity to learn more about the trials, see the vehicles that will be used and learn more about the potential applications of AV technologies.The event takes place at ORIC — the former Stromness Primary School — from pm to pm and there is no need to book.In Orkney, small AVs will undergo initial trials for logistics and freight purposes, such as the transport of general supplies, luggage, parcels, waste and other goods.These AVs will move at walking pace and work is ongoing to identy a shortlist of potential routes and uses.In a larger scale project in Inverness, an AV passenger service will be provided between Inverness Campus and Inverness Retail and Business Park. Safety is paramount and although the vehicle used will be capable of driving itself, a driver will be present at all times to take controlrequired.Widespread use of self-driving vehicles is expected by next decade and the findings of the project will be used to determine how countries across Europe can effectively implement them # including considering how they fit in with green transport and spatial planning strategies, as well as likely socio-economic impacts.Representatives from the project partners will be in attendance including HITRANS , More Work Less Carbon — a company based in Utrecht, Netherlands, who will supply the AVs — and Robert Gordon University.copy The Orcadian - A ision of Orkney Media Group Ltd Co. title: orbital turbine reaches global summit
story: Orbital Marine Power has been chosen as one of only  companies invited to take part in this month#s Global Investment Summit , hosted by the Prime Minister and supported by members of the Royal Family.Set to take place on October  in London, the summit aims to showcase the most innovative green technologies and companies already operating in the UK and will highlight the UK’s leading global position and commitment to Net Zero.Working towards delivery of the Prime Minister’s Ten Point Plan for a Green Industrial Revolution, the Summit will bring  of the world’s most prominent decision makers, C-Suite executives, and investors to the UK.The Hatston-based company will be exhibiting its ground-breaking tidal technology, having delivered its MW turbine O to Orkney back in May.Orbital CEO, Andrew Scott, said: “Being selected to exhibit at the Global Investment Summit is a huge honour for Orbital Marine Power and a unique opportunity for us to showcase our bold vision that can help turn the tide on climate change to some of the most influential investors in the world.”The O turbine project has also gained praise from UK investment minister, Gerry Grimestone, ahead of the summit.Mr Grimestone said: #The Global Investment Summit will put UK innovation on the map and demonstrate how we can use investment to nurture technological developments and propel our economy towards a more prosperous, exciting future.#Our showcase businesses show why the UK is a global hub for green technology, and I am proud that Orbital Marine Power will be presenting their innovative tidal turbine technology to some of the world#s most high profile investors at the summit.#Our industries of the future like tidal will not only help ensure a cleaner, greener planet but also create high value jobs in Scotland and across the UK.#copy The Orcadian - A ision of Orkney Media Group Ltd Co. title: orkney grind their way to bonus point win at picky
story: A gritty and determined Orkney RFC beat old rivals Caithness to record a third bonus-point victory on the bounce.Scott Russell opened the scoring in the - win, ing under the posts to get Orkney off to the perfect start on a bright but windy day in Kirkwall.Caithness replied with a converted try of their own to make it -, before Orkney captain Scott Rendall forced his way over the line to put the home side back into the lead.The visitors squared the game before the break though, making it - at half-time.Ally Linklater was the next to go over the line in the second half for a converted try, but Caithness fought back once more, bringing the score to -.With space at a premium on the flanks, it was through direct powerful forward play that Orkney continued to profit from. title: stagecoach pay offer aims to halt industrial action
story: newsStagecoach pay offer aims to halt industrial actionOctober ,  at : amStagecoach has submitted a fresh pay offer in a bid to prevent industrial action by workers in Orkney and across the Highlands.Confirming its offer, this Thursday morning, Stagecoach Highlands said it hoped to break the deadlock and reach an agreement with trade union Unite.New deals will be put to Unite in talks next week covering employees in Kirkwall, Inverness, Tain, Portree, Thurso, and Aviemore.This follows warnings from Unite that bus transport in these areas could be #brought to a halt# this autumns, as its members ballot on whether to take industrial action short of a strike.In a release from Stagecoach, this morning, Stagecoach Highlands# managing director, David Beaton, said: #Buses are a leline for local people across the Highlands and Islands. We are committed to ensuring our people who keep our communities connected are properly rewarded, particularly after their contribution to the country over the past  months of the pandemic.“We have worked tirelessly to protect the jobs of our people during the pandemic and done everything we reasonably can to hold constructive discussions with Unite to reach a sensible and sustainable pay agreement across our bus depots.“We are leaving no stone unturned in a bid to reach a settlement. That is why we are putting a fresh pay offer to Unite in talks scheduled to take place next week.”According to Stagecoach, bus services are facing a continuing challenging financial environment with passenger levels signicantly down on pre-COVID levels. Passenger fares are signicantly short of what is needed to cover the day-to-day costs of running services without Scottish Government support.Mr Beaton added: “We would urge Unite to end the uncertainty for our people and the customers who rely on bus services.“Strike action is completely unnecessary and would simply damage the lives and livelihoods of hard-working people, including our employees, as well as the region’s businesses.#We would urge Unite to put communities first and talk, not walk.”copy The Orcadian - A ision of Orkney Media Group Ltd Co. Property Section for what they thought was a snip at £k and decided to use part of a trust fund to purchase it as a commercial investment.They thought that they could also capitalise on the local tourist ‘boom’ and have applied to turn the derelict croft house into a vegan cafe and craft shop and also to stick several pods on their newly acquired croft to offer a ‘holistic getaway’ for their jet-set pals.Do you, and I certainly don’t mean to pre-judge anyone who reads this paperthink that their ‘cases’ should be treated any dferently by the local planning authorities If the answer is “yes”, then think again.Too dficult a scenario to judge Try this one.Should an application to build a couple of pods on a croft, which is basically  per cent bog, in the middle of Ranish and has no view of anywhere except adjacent croft bog, be given any additional merit over a similar application in beautul Scaristavore or Ardroil where ‘breathtaking scenery’ will be the selling tagline Wrong again.As a member of the local planning board here in the Western Isles, I’m more than well aware of what my responsibilities are and it’s certainly not to pre-judge any applications based on my own preconceptions, or prejudicesof what should or shouldn’t be allowed.I’ve to stick to the guidelines and the training I’ve been given, understand what’s expected of meand to base my decision without emotion or bias. across the front pages of this paper and others, on social media and the television news, can influence any of my our decisions.The capitalist playground which crofting tenure has now become, and the seismic change in the scale of speculation on ‘marketable’ properties available, is in danger of knocking the fragile socio-economic balance of the west of Scotland even further off its already very shoogly axis.Crofts have now become the equivalent of crypto-currency the ‘Bitcoins’ which can provide financial security for those fortunate enough to be sitting on ‘gold’.What’s being done to stabilise and bring a dose of reality to a market which threatens to get completely out of control How can single iniduals be able to own several crofts with not an intention to ‘work’ or develop any single one of them I believe that a crofting historian once said that this form of land tenure has become ‘the single biggest impediment to sustainable development in Western Scotland and the Highlands and Islands’.That wasn’t yesterday.‘Things’ are already well out of control.But who should intervene I’m not the only one who keeps asking the question.Apparently ‘we’ should legislate to address.We need, it has been suggested, to become Jersey or Guernsey.That people shouldn’t be allowed to buy homes here unless they intend to be used as a primary residence .Second homes taxation needs to increase signicantly and the additional income be used to support tourism infrastructure.From the Butt to Bodmin there have been ious proposals as to how to legislate to prevent the worst effects of tourism from destroying fragile local economies.Have any worked, andso, could they be implemented here to make any dference Let me be very clear.Tourism is hugely important to our rural economy.More so since Brexit and Covid.But I’ll say this again, at the risk of boring you all: it needs to be carefully nurtured and sustainably developed.We cannot survivewe turn our villages into ‘ghost-towns’#yes, I know…..for the winter months.We need a balance, we need the ‘tools’ with which to legislate properly and we need those charged with ‘oversight’ to take better ownership.We need, and I’ve yet to see any evidence of this, these same people to begin to take this seriously.For our future generations.They are the ones who will be impacted mostwe don’t sit up and pay attention.Now.

title: remember your roots skye plan is urged to recognise
story: An Tìr, An Cànan, ‘S na DaoineThose were the comments of Roddy Murray, former Western Isles councillor and now the grazings clerk for Tarskavaig in Sleat, who this week voiced his concern that there was no mention of crofting at all in the ‘Skye and Raasay Future’ plan published in August with the full backing of all four local councillors.He told the Free Press: “There are  projects listed in the plan but not a single mention of crofting. Crofting is the basis for so many of the settlements on Skye outwith Portree, Broadford and Kyleakin and this should have been acknowledged.“There is quite a signicant impact from crofting on the economic and social well-being of Skye and Raasay. You only have to look at the , high quality calves sold for high prices last week in Portree to see that.”In terms of infrastructure improvements to support crofting, Mr Murray said the auction mart in Portree must be redeveloped to improve parking and animal welfare, and an abattoir facility must be provided so that livestock does not have to be driven to Dingwall.He added: “We are being told by the Scottish Crofting Federation that there is a huge demand for new crofts.#To meet that demand we either have to encourage landowners to make this happen or there has to be acquisition of an estate.“If we want to keep our young people in our communities we need to address the availability of crofts.”The Scottish Government are guilty of an “abject failure” when it comes to creating new crofts on publicly-owned land, Mr Murray added.Stung by the criticism, the council said they hoped to “discuss the plan further with organisations like the Crofting Commission” and would be keen to hear from any other interested parties.A spokeswoman said: “Skye and Raasay Future has been prepared with and by wider representatives of the community across the area.#It reflects people’s vision and priorities for the future, following feedback gathered through workshops and online consultations held throughout the year.“In workshop discussions, the important role that crofting plays in the identity and culture of Skye and Raasay communities has been clearly referenced..#Skye councillor John Finlayson said all stakeholders should be involved in “shaping, evaluating and changing” the plan’s priorities and he acknowledged the importance of crofting “in all its guises” across Skye and Raasay.He added: “Crofting is still a central part of le on Skye and while it is part of our history and culture it will also I hope continue to be a key part of our future and it is an important element of SARF.#As those who took part in the engagement to create the initial plan agreed, it is important that representatives from the crofting community are fully engaged in the continued development and implementation of the plan and I am confident this will happen.”

title: children in school bus collision traumatised parent
story: A parent of youngsters who were travelling on the school bus caught up in a serious traffic collision this morning on the Cullybackey Road says he fears that a number of children will have been traumatised by the incident. The man, who rushed to the scene in the immediate aftermath said the collision had taken place roughly half way between the layby at the crest of the hill above Ballymena and the Woodtown Junction.“This was a very serious incident and I do know that a lot of children have received bumps and bruises and I also fear that some may yet be diagnosed with hairline fractures.“I’m sure a lot of those children will have been deeply shocked.” One man has been taken to hospital via Air Ambulance which was tasked to the scene.Police were operating ersions at Woodtown Junction and near the mph sign on the Cullybackey Road.

title: get your flu jab at your community pharmacy
story: You are now able to receive your flu vaccine at your local community pharmacy. The Chief Medical Officer, Professor Sir Michael McBride, and Chief Pharmaceutical Officer, Cathy Harrison, recently officially launched this year’s community pharmacy flu vaccination programme and have received their flu jab in Belfast.The seasonal influenza programme officially began on October , ,and this year the programme is being expanded to help protect the most vulnerable people in our society and to relieve the winter pressures being faced by the health service during the ongoing COVID- pandemic.The rollout of the seasonal flu vaccination programme in Northern Ireland will be supported by community pharmacies across the province who will be offering the vaccine to: All adults aged  years and over as well as all HSC workers.Speaking at Balmoral Pharmacy, the Chief Medical Officer, Professor Sir Michael McBride, said: “The COVID- pandemic continues to place signicant demands and pressures on our Health Service and we expect that there will be circulation of both flu and COVID- this winter, which will inevitably add further pressures on our already fragile health care system.“As a result of the low flu activity last winter we expect reduced levels of population immunity against the virus this winter.“In the situation where social mixing and social contacttowards pre-pandemic norms, it is expected that this winter will be the first winter in the UK when seasonal flu and other respiratory viruses such as RSV in children will circulate alongside COVID-.“Modelling indicates the   flu season in the UK could be up to % larger than typically seen and it is also possible that the  to  influenza season will begin earlier than usual. Influenza vaccination is therefore an important priority this coming autumn to reduce morbidity and mortality associated with influenza, and to reduce hospitalisations during a time when the health service may also be managing signicant winter outbreaks of COVID-. Please keep following the public advice to reduce the transmission of flu and COVID-, please get the vaccines and protect yourself, those that matter to you and the health service.”The extension of the community pharmacy role in the   flu vaccination programme will offer an additional route to vaccination for all HSC workers and for all those aged  and over, complimenting existing Occupational Health services and GP services, in order to maximise uptake of the flu vaccine.Chief Pharmaceutical Officer, Mrs Cathy Harrison, said: “Community pharmacists are highly trained healthcare professionals and have continued to play a pivotal role delivering health services to communities in Northern Ireland during the pandemic.“I am delighted to welcome this expanded role for community pharmacy teams, which builds on the success of last year’s community pharmacy flu vaccination service and the COVID- vaccination programme, which has seen over , doses of COVID- vaccine administered in community pharmacies all across Northern Ireland.“This service will complement the already strong arrangements for delivering the flu vaccination programme in Trusts and general practice. And will use the skills of community pharmacy teams to provide much needed additional capacity across the healthcare system to deliver the largest flu vaccination programme ever at the same time as the COVID- booster vaccination programme and maintaining provision of other essential HSC services.”Chief Executive of Community Pharmacy NI, Gerard Greene, said: “Community pharmacies across Northern Ireland welcome the expansion of the Community Pharmacy flu vaccination service, it gives the public the option of getting their flu vaccine at a convenient, accessible location with a local pharmacist they know and trust.

title: wrightbus honoured to showcase to the world
story: THE world’s first hydrogen double decker bus will be on display to the world after its maker, Wrightbus, was chosen to be part of a prestigious event showcasing the best green innovations in the UK.Wrightbus was selected as one of  green innovators from across the nation to take part in the Government-hosted Global Investment Summit on October , which will showcase the best of UK innovation and green technology.Hosted by the Prime Minister and supported by members of the Royal Family, the Summit will demonstrate Britain’s commitment to green industries of the future ahead of COP and promote the UK as the best destination for foreign investment.Around  investors attending the Summit will see the latest cutting-edge innovation - including Wrightbus’s world-first hydrogen double decker - that is helping deliver key areas of the PM’s Ten Point Plan, helping cement the UK’s position as a science superpower and the world’s number one centre for green technology.The event aims to drive billions of pounds of investment across the UK.Wrightbus owner and Executive Chairman, Jo Bamford, said he was proud to be showcasing the firm’s world-leading technology at the event alongside other UK innovators.“We’re honoured to have been invited to showcase our world-first Hydroliner hydrogen double decker bus at the prestigious Global Investment Summit,” he said.“Thanks to investment into research and development, Wrightbus has become a true world-leader in zero-emission bus transport technology. From the launch of the world’s first hydrogen double deck bus to the launch of the fastest-charging EV double deck on the market, our innovation in the sector is unsurpassed.“To date, our zero-carbon buses have covered more than half a million miles, preventing almost  million kg of CO from entering the atmosphere on those journeys. We need to ensure hydrogen-powered transportation is a viable and cost effective alternative for the UK to hit its net zero objectives.“We’re proud to be part of the movement that’s leading the world to create technological solutions to ensure a net zero future, whilst also creating green jobs and boosting the UK’s green economy.“As a nation, we could create a world-leading hydrogen ecosystem allowing us to become one of the best hydrogen-producing countries in the world - but continued investment into the sector is vital for such projects to have a truly global impact.”The Ten Point Plan will mobilise poundbn of government investment to create and support up to , highly skilled green jobs in the UK - and unlock three times as much private sector investment by . In the last decade Foreign Direct Investmenthas created more than , jobs across the country, and since April  projects supported by the Department for International Trade have contributed more than pound billion to the economy.Inward investment also helps level up the UK by making companies more profitable, which means they can invest back into local economies and stronger supply chains, and more sustainable communities for the future.Minister for Investment Gerry Grimstone said: The Global Investment Summit will put UK innovation on the map and demonstrate how we can use investment to nurture technological developments and propel our economy towards a more prosperous, exciting future.Our showcase businesses show why the UK is a global hub for green technology, and I am proud that Wrightbus will be presenting their innovative world-first zero-emission double decker hydrogen bus to some of the worlds most high profile investors at the summit.Our industries of the future like automotive will not only help ensure a cleaner, greener planet but also create high value jobs in Northern Ireland and across the UK.

title: coronavirus northern ireland changes to social distancing what remains in rules and how to avoid an accidental rave
story: Photo by Jonathan Porter Press Eye First Minister Paul Givan and Deputy First Minister Michelle ONeill pictured today at Stormont press call.First Minister Paul Givan and Deputy First Minister Michelle O#Neill. Credit: PAPA FacebookTwitterEmailWhatsapp,"onDemand":true,"lazyload":truePhoto by Jonathan Porter Press Eye First Minister Paul Givan and Deputy First Minister Michelle ONeill pictured today at Stormont press call.Christopher LeebodyTwitterEmailOctober   : AMFacebookTwitterEmailThe Executive agreed a number of signicant changes to Northern Ireland’s coronavirus restrictions on Thursday, with key dates throughout October.Ministers met at Stormont to discuss some of the outstanding aspects of lockdown, including changes to social distancing and the full reopening of the hospitality industry and nightclubs.There were also changes to rules around indoor gatherings and further discussion on vaccine certicate proposals.Read MoreCoronavirus NI: Ending social distancing will help hospitality ‘bounce back’What is changing on October :The first landmark date this month will see changes to rules around the numbers who can gather in private domestic settings.From Thursday October , the restrictions on the number of people allowed to meet inside a home is to be increased from  people from four households, to  people from an unlimited number of households.While rules around indoor gatherings are being eased, the Executive confirmed both raves and private house parties are still not permitted.While someone can organise  people to gather for a dinner party or catchup, rules define a “large house party” or rave as having “more than  persons at a private dwelling”.Ministers also defined a rave as a private indoor gathering of more than  at which: “Amplied music is played during the night with or without intermission which is likely to cause serious distress to inhabitants of the locality by reason of its loudness, duration and the time at which it is played.”Separately on this date, audience members will no longer need to be seated when watching indoor performances.What is changing on October :The key date in Northern Ireland’s journey through the pandemic comes on Halloween night, with changes to social distancing and nightclubs finally getting the green light to reopen.It’s good news for the hospitality sector with the need to maintain social distancing in bars and restaurants no longer required.Under existing rules, social distancing of at least mremains a legal requirement in pubs, bars and restaurants in Northern Ireland.Regulations around social distancing will instead move into guidance for establishments to consider.The changes to social distancing mean therefore people will be allowed to freely move around hospitality settings into pre-pandemic normality.This includes standing to have a drink or eat food.It’s good news for those who like to take to the stage, with dancing permitted indoors.With that change also comes the reopening of nightclubs.Expand" " class"c-lightbox-top-close icon-close" data-closeCloseFirst Minister Paul Givan and Deputy First Minister Michelle O#Neill. Credit: PAPA FacebookTwitterEmailWhatsapp,"onDemand":true,"lazyload":trueFirst Minister Paul Givan and Deputy First Minister Michelle O#Neill. Credit: PAWhat about mask wearing The Executive did not make any specic changes to the current rules around mask wearing in certain indoor settings such as public transport.The requirement to wear face coverings in certain settings is being retained as part of the Executive’s winter contingency plans.There is no indication as yet though how this requirement will operate when hospitality settings fully reopen at the end of this month, with the latest rules from the Executive specying the requirement to wear one will be retained in “certain settings, such as in shops, shopping centres and public transport”.What about vaccine certicates The Executive did not make the use of a vaccine certicate mandatory for people to access hospitality venues at the end of this month.Instead, they will ask event organisers and venues to voluntarily introduce entry systems requiring patrons to either prove full vaccination or a negative lateral flow test, or evidence of a Covid infection within the previous six months.During the meeting, it is understood ministers were told by officials that indoor seated venues that have introduced vaccine test proof entry requirements in recent weeks have seen a % compliance rate among patrons.Ministers did confirm that the option of having a certication system is being considered as part of potential winter contingency planscases begin to rise.They said plans to have a Covid vaccine certicate “in certain settings” are being considered as part of those contingencies.Deputy First Minister Michelle O’Neill said she does not “want to go down the mandatory route”.First Minister Paul Givan said he hopes a voluntary arrangement with the hospitality industry “will work”.Read MoreLeaders rule out mandatory jab passportsWhat the political leaders said:Speaking to the media after the announcement of the changes, First Minister Paul Givan said he was “pleased” about the changes agreed.There will be three areas left that will be the wearing of face coverings in some limited areas, when it comes to the retention of risk assessments and also the retention of data around visitors to venues and hospitality,” he said.They will be low-level mitigation measures which will stay in law, there will be guidance when it comes to a lot of the sectors that are operating across our society and economy that will remain in place in a voluntary guidance format.By the end of October we will have moved to the point where there are three areas that we will continue to look at over the course of the winter and will likely remain as low-level regulatory interventions.On October  we will have changes in terms of numbers around the domestic settings and tourist accommodation. That will be limited still in respect of house parties and raves. That will happen on October  and the remaining areas then at the end of October.Deputy First Minister Michelle O’Neill referenced the progress that has been made but sounded a note of caution on the months ahead.There are measures which we don#t want to be in a place to introduce but we have to be ready for that just in case we get to that point,” she said.We#re in for an uncertain period ahead and we have to work our way through that as best we can.We#re going to do everything we can to avoid getting to that point.”Most ReadTop Northern Ireland hotel sold in £m deal to US investment FacebookTwitterEmailWhatsapp,"onDemand":true,"lazyload":trueDevelopment: The site of the George Best Hotel in Belfast city centreAllan PrestonTwitterEmailOctober   : PMFacebookTwitterEmailThe family of George Best have withdrawn permission for developers to name a Belfast hotel after the Manchester United and Northern Ireland football legend from the east of the city.It follows an announcement in July that local businessmen were working to finish the troubled project which had been hit by financial delays.Work on the George Best Hotel in the historic Scottish Mutual Building at Donegall Square stalled in April  when the owners, Bedford Hotels Ltd, a subsidiary of Liverpool-based Signature Living Hotels Ltd, went bankrupt, leaving investors owed millions.In July, a -strong group of investors announced they would collaborate with Signature Living’s owner, Lawrence Kenwright, to save the development and their investments.However, on Wednesday night, the directors of the George Best company, the late footballer’s family, said they wanted to clary their position, and said that they were not among those investors.“The family terminated all connections with Signature Living earlier this year and in fact are in amongst the creditors currently being handled by the official receiver,” they said in a statement.“Furthermore they have not and will not be committing George’s name to any proposed redevelopment of the site as may have been construed in the article referred to above.”Daily Headlines  EveningNewsletterReceive today#s headlines directly to your inbox every morning and evening, with our free daily newsletter.Enter email addressThis field is requiredSign Up The family added that they “maintain their belief” in the ultimate potential of a hotel “and desire to see a successful scheme completed in the city”.In July, Mr Kenwright said he invited the new group of investors to become part of the George Best Hotel property company, hoping their combined weight would make it easier to get funding to complete the hotel.The group is now chaired by Co Antrim businessman Stephen Kearney, who will now oversee refinancing and development, with Mr Kenwright taking on the role of CEO.After originally investing in the hotel in , he admitted in July that it had been “a turbulent journey” for Signature Living but there was now hope the matter could be resolved with the George Best Hotel administration.The GB Hotel group is also being advised by another Northern Irish businessman, Thomas Scullion, who is himself a Signature Living investor. He is the chair of the UK Accommodation Group , which he set up with fellow investors to restructure Signature Living#s operations last September.Mr Kearney had said that UKAG had “mobilised the vast majority of unsecured investors in supporting Lawrence Kenwright and have worked diligently on a recovery plan”, and said that “crucially Lawrence has handed over control” of operations.Mr Kenwright had admitted he was “ceding controland giving them final say in decisions”. He added: “We have faced a unique set of circumstances in trying to finish the George Best Hotel and I am extremely grateful for this support.”Signature Living did not respond to a request for comment by time of going to press on Wednesday night..app-box.app-box h.app-box a.app-box img Download the BelfastAppGet quick and easy title: belfast council accused of snub to chinese community for refusing funding to confucius institute
story: Belfast City HallGetty Images FacebookTwitterEmailWhatsapp,"onDemand":true,"lazyload":trueBelfast City HallBy Michael Kenwood, Local Democracy ReporterOctober   : PMFacebookTwitterEmailBelfast Council has been accused of a “snub” to the Chinese community in the city, for refusing funding to the Confucius Institute.DUP councillor Brian Kingston made the claim after an SDLP motion declining a £, grant to the Institute was passed with majority support at Monday’s full council meeting.The Confucius Institute in Northern Ireland was established in partnership with the Ulster University in Belfast in  and has a role comparable to the British Council, promoting Chinese culture, education and language across the world.However, it has also been described as an expression of Chinese ‘soft power’ and one of the country’s diplomatic weapons in its ambition to become the world’s main superpower.At the council’s City Growth and Regeneration Committee meeting last month, SDLP councillor Donal Lyons forwarded a proposal to refuse financial support for the Confucius Institute, against council officer advice, during a debate on City Hall’s international engagement activities.The committee agreed to decline the fundin on the basis that it was “associated with the Chinese state government, which has a select approach on how it conducts its business” and Belfast City Council “should not deepen its relationship by developing a memorandum of understanding”.SDLP councillors made reference to the Chinese state’s record of human rights abuses, and concerns relating to “espionage”.Daily Headlines  EveningNewsletterReceive today#s headlines directly to your inbox every morning and evening, with our free daily newsletter.Enter email addressThis field is requiredSign Up Mr Kingston told the full council chamber on Monday: “I regard this as something of a snub, and an unnecessary insult to those from the Chinese community in this city, and to China.“The Confucius Institute is an organisation that does a lot of very positive work in Northern Ireland.“If people have issues with the Chinese government, or have political issues with China, it should not interfere with city-to-city good relations, and good relations with our Chinese community here.“The Chinese community is one of the longest standing, and largest international ethnic communities here in Belfast, and they would look to the Confucius Institute for support.”A DUP amendment to approve the grant failed on Monday evening, with  votes against from Sinn Fein, the SDLP, the Greens and People Before Profit. Seventeen elected members voted in favour, from the DUP, the PUP and the UUP, while  Alliance members abstained.The decision went against recommendations from council officers, who advised the council should give the £, to the Confucius Institute.The council’s Director of Economic Development told a committee the institute had been “working closely with those NI councils that are engaged in activity within China, and had greatly assisted Belfast City Council in its work with sister city Shenyang since ”.The director said the institute “had engaged with the council to explore the potential to enter into a memorandum of understanding in order to formalise the support services and agree an outline activity plan” and “considered that this approach would help them manage resources more effectively”.Councillor Lyons told the chamber: “In appreciating Chinese culture I do not appreciate bits of it being eroded to suit the political agenda of the organisation that finances this institute.”He said: “This is about creating a memorandum of understanding about formalised support services – I don’t know what that means. To agree on an activity of events – what are these events, and what are the aims of these events  What is the content of them  The report doesn’t go into any of this.”He added: “And I won’t take lessons on needless snubs from the DUP – lessons on needlessly insulting our international family, as well as brothers and sisters from a dferent city. I find that a bit hypocritical.”SDLP Councillor Seamus De Faoite told the council there had been concerns raised “on the issue of espionage.” He said: “I will quote the MP Fiona Bruce directly when she says there are “serious concerns about the presence of the Confucius Institute on university campuses within the UK”.“That follows on from concerns from the US state department regarding the Confucius Institute and their role in universities there, in terms of suppressing freedom of speech and effectively propagating the institutions of the Chinese Communist party in other countries.“We cannot orce our international relations and connections of this city from any of the issues around human rights abuses and concerns we have in relation to China, or in fact any other country.”He added: “I think it is very important we orce the idea of the Chinese government being representative of the Chinese people. Similarly for other people around the world – they are not necessarily represented by the government of the jurisdiction in which they live.“I think it is also very important we don’t confuse those issues, in an attempt to suggest any opposition to the Confucius Institute and its presence in Belfast is in any way some kind of latent racism.”.app-box.app-box h.app-box a.app-box img Download the story: Queen Elizabeth, the Cunard Line giant, arrives the day after the largest liner to visit Belfast in modern times Expand" " class"c-lightbox-top-close icon-close" data-closeCloseRoyal Caribbean’s Anthem of the Seas cruise liner sails into Belfast lough yesterday. Credit: Stephen HamiltonStephen Hamilton FacebookTwitterEmailWhatsapp,"onDemand":true,"lazyload":trueRoyal Caribbean’s Anthem of the Seas cruise liner sails into Belfast lough yesterday. Credit: Stephen HamiltonJohn BreslinOctober   : AMFacebookTwitterEmailIt slipped through the waters in the dark of the night, due to dock before dawn to become the ,th cruise ship to arrive in Belfast in the modern era.Queen Elizabeth, the Cunard Line giant, will on Thursday mark a milestone that will be welcomed by many, including city leaders and those in the tourism industry.According to its itinerary, the £m, ft, , tonne vessel was steered around Britain over the last five days before its expected arrival at .am on Thursday morning at the cruise terminal.While the Queen Elizabeth may be an impressive size, even it was dwarfed by the largest cruise ship to visit Belfast in modern times — Royal Caribbean’s Anthem of the Seas, number  on the docking list at Belfast.Anthem of the Seas, ,ft with a , capacity and  decks, left Belfast on Wednesday evening following a day visit. A third giant, PO’s Azura is currently undergoing work in Belfast ahead of its winter deployment in the Caribbean.The Queen Elizabeth first appeared in October  when she was named in a ceremony by the Queen herself. It can take , passengers and has , cabins — including  suites,  balcony,  ocean view and  inside. Daily Headlines  EveningNewsletterReceive today#s headlines directly to your inbox every morning and evening, with our free daily newsletter.Enter email addressThis field is requiredSign Up Joanne Stuart, chief executive of the NI Tourism Alliance, last night welcomed the milestone, describing the sharp increase in the number of ships docking as a real boost to the economy.“It is great to see this milestone celebrated and it is down to the amazing work of everyone involved at Belfast Harbour,” Ms Stuart said, adding that the number of ships docking has doubled in the three years to .Pre-pandemic, in , some , cruise passengers visited Belfast, a record, pumping around £m into the wider economy, but that is a conservative estimate, the tourism industry advocate said.“It is good for tour guides, bus operators and dferent regions benefit as day trips are organised to the Ards Peninsula or the Giant’s Causeway,” Ms Stuart said.“Independent travellers also take a trip on their own into Belfast.”“There are also benefits bringing new people to Belfast, with stories of them coming back, either for leisure or business,” added Ms Stuart, who also pointed out that Londonderry also saw increases in cruise traffic, which she described as really important.The first cruise ship of the modern era docked in Belfast  years ago, and the first dedicated terminal for the liners on
